x_l: The Russian central bank is concerned that the recent U.S. and European sanctions on Russia could slow Russian exports to Europe, hurting the economy. The central bank in May proposed raising the cost of foreign currency borrowing for Russian companies to cover capital and other outflows from the country and for its government. While Russia has long been a net exporter to Europe, the Kremlin has repeatedly warned that it would retaliate if the EU imposes further sanctions, and it has been looking to Europe to help finance its military equipment and equipment for foreign projects, which Russia is barred from doing.
y_orig: The Russian central Bank has also been looking for ways to increase its foreign exchange reserves to offset the impact of the sanctions.
y_summ: The Russian central Bank has been seeking to bolster its foreign currency reserves to avoid a currency crisis, and to help offset the impact of sanctions.

x_l: In an interview that will be broadcast Sunday on CBS' "60 Minutes," Osama bin Laden, the leader of al Qaeda, described the Taliban as "moderate Muslims," saying that they did not attack the United States. But he also said that some of the most prominent Taliban leaders were "terrorists," including his son, Saad. Mr. Bin Laden, in the first television interview he has given since Sept. 11, suggested that the United States was trying to discredit Islam and that its support for the Taliban was a sign that the United States could not protect Muslims.
y_orig: "The American government is trying to destroy the image of Islam in the world," he said.
y_summ: "The United States is trying to undermine the Islamic religion," he said.

x_l: A woman from South Africa has developed an app that can predict which men will cheat, according to BBC News. The app, called "The Predictor," is a combination of a smartphone and a series of questions about someone's behavior. The questions ask about the woman's sexual history and whether she has had past sexual partners. It's unclear when the app will be available for use but the South African government plans to roll out the app to all of its citizens starting next year.
